name: Prediction & Specialized
description: Prediction model sample size, precision-based CI, diagnostic accuracy, and specialized methods

tasks.question: A gerontologist is evaluating a rapid antigen test for respiratory infections. The expected sensitivity is 0.9 and the clinically acceptable margin (delta) is 0.1. At significance level 0.05 with 80% power, how many diseased subjects are needed to confirm that the true sensitivity exceeds 0.8?

A sports medicine physician is evaluating a new blood biomarker panel for early cancer detection. The expected sensitivity is 0.85 and the clinically acceptable margin (delta) is 0.1. At significance level 0.05 with 80% power, how many diseased subjects are needed to confirm that the true sensitivity exceeds 0.75?

A allergist is evaluating a point-of-care screening tool for cardiac events. The expected sensitivity is 0.9 and the clinically acceptable margin (delta) is 0.05. At significance level 0.05 with 80% power, how many diseased subjects are needed to confirm that the true sensitivity exceeds 0.85?

A urologist is evaluating an imaging-based diagnostic for neurological disorders. The expected sensitivity is 0.95 and the clinically acceptable margin (delta) is 0.05. At significance level 0.05 with 90% power, how many diseased subjects are needed to confirm that the true sensitivity exceeds 0.9?

A hematologist is evaluating a serological assay for autoimmune conditions. The expected specificity is 0.9 and the clinically acceptable margin (delta) is 0.1. At significance level 0.05 with 80% power, how many diseased subjects are needed to confirm that the true specificity exceeds 0.8?

A clinical nutritionist is evaluating a genomic screening test for hereditary conditions. The expected specificity is 0.95 and the clinically acceptable margin (delta) is 0.05. At significance level 0.05 with 90% power, how many diseased subjects are needed to confirm that the true specificity exceeds 0.9?

A rehabilitation specialist is evaluating a novel urinalysis panel for renal disease. The expected sensitivity is 0.9 with a clinically acceptable margin (delta) of 0.1. With 100 diseased subjects available, what power does the study achieve at significance level 0.05?

A pediatrician is designing a study to validate the AUC of an AI-assisted imaging tool for fracture detection. The expected AUC is 0.8 and the minimum acceptable AUC margin (delta) is 0.1. At significance level 0.05 with 80% power, how many subjects are needed to show the AUC significantly exceeds 0.7?

A endocrinologist is designing a study to validate the AUC of a saliva-based screening for metabolic disorders. The expected AUC is 0.9 and the minimum acceptable AUC margin (delta) is 0.05. At significance level 0.05 with 80% power, how many subjects are needed to show the AUC significantly exceeds 0.85?

A orthopedic surgeon is designing a study to validate the AUC of a wearable sensor for arrhythmia detection. The expected AUC is 0.75 and the minimum acceptable AUC margin (delta) is 0.1. At significance level 0.05 with 90% power, how many subjects are needed to show the AUC significantly exceeds 0.65?

A gastroenterologist needs to validate the sensitivity of a rapid antigen test for respiratory infections. The expected sensitivity is 0.9 with an acceptable deviation (delta) of 0.1. At significance level 0.05 with 80% power, how many truly positive subjects are needed?

A pulmonologist needs to validate the specificity of a new blood biomarker panel for early cancer detection. The expected specificity is 0.9 with an acceptable deviation (delta) of 0.1. At significance level 0.05 with 80% power, how many truly negative subjects are needed?

A rheumatologist needs to validate the sensitivity of a point-of-care screening tool for cardiac events. The expected sensitivity is 0.95 with an acceptable deviation (delta) of 0.05. At significance level 0.05 with 80% power, how many truly positive subjects are needed?
A nurse researcher wants to estimate a parameter of interest with a specified 95% confidence interval precision. How many subjects are needed for this precision?
A social scientist wants to estimate a parameter of interest with a specified 95% confidence interval precision. How many subjects are needed for this precision?

A gerontologist is developing a clinical prediction model for a binary outcome. The model includes 20 candidate predictors. The expected Cox-Snell R² is 0.25. The expected outcome prevalence is 15%. Using the Riley criteria, what minimum sample size is needed to avoid overfitting and ensure adequate predictive performance?

A sports medicine physician is developing a clinical prediction model for a binary outcome. The model includes 10 candidate predictors. The expected Cox-Snell R² is 0.15. The expected outcome prevalence is 10%. Using the Riley criteria, what minimum sample size is needed to avoid overfitting and ensure adequate predictive performance?

A allergist is developing a clinical prediction model for a binary outcome. The model includes 15 candidate predictors. The expected Cox-Snell R² is 0.2. The expected outcome prevalence is 20%. Using the Riley criteria, what minimum sample size is needed to avoid overfitting and ensure adequate predictive performance?

A urologist is developing a clinical prediction model for a binary outcome. The model includes 30 candidate predictors. The expected Cox-Snell R² is 0.3. The expected outcome prevalence is 20%. Using the Riley criteria, what minimum sample size is needed to avoid overfitting and ensure adequate predictive performance?

A hematologist is developing a clinical prediction model for a binary outcome. The model includes 15 candidate predictors. The expected Cox-Snell R² is 0.2. The expected outcome prevalence is 5%. Using the Riley criteria, what minimum sample size is needed to avoid overfitting and ensure adequate predictive performance?

A clinical nutritionist is developing a clinical prediction model for a binary outcome. The model includes 25 candidate predictors. The expected Cox-Snell R² is 0.1. The expected outcome prevalence is 30%. Using the Riley criteria, what minimum sample size is needed to avoid overfitting and ensure adequate predictive performance?

A rehabilitation specialist is developing a clinical prediction model for a binary outcome. The model includes 20 candidate predictors. The expected outcome prevalence is 15%. Using the Riley criteria, what minimum sample size is needed to avoid overfitting and ensure adequate predictive performance?

A occupational therapist is developing a clinical prediction model for a binary outcome. The model includes 24 candidate predictors. The expected Cox-Snell R² is 0.288. The expected outcome prevalence is 17%. Using the Riley criteria, what minimum sample size is needed to avoid overfitting and ensure adequate predictive performance?

A speech pathologist is developing a clinical prediction model for a binary outcome. The model includes 24 candidate predictors. The expected outcome prevalence is 17%. Using the Riley criteria, what minimum sample size is needed to avoid overfitting and ensure adequate predictive performance?

A physical therapist is developing a clinical prediction model for a binary outcome. The model includes 10 candidate predictors. The expected Cox-Snell R² is 0.2. The expected outcome prevalence is 10%. Using the Riley criteria, what minimum sample size is needed to avoid overfitting and ensure adequate predictive performance?
tasks.reference_code:
library(pmsampsize)
pmsampsize(type="b", csrsquared=0.20, parameters=10, prevalence=0.10, shrinkage=0.95)

tasks.question: A cardiologist is developing a clinical prediction model for a time-to-event outcome. The model includes 15 candidate predictors. The expected Cox-Snell R² is 0.1. Using the Riley criteria, what minimum sample size is needed to avoid overfitting and ensure adequate predictive performance?
tasks.reference_code:
library(pmsampsize)
pmsampsize(type="s", csrsquared=0.10, parameters=15, rate=0.10, timepoint=2, meanfup=3)

tasks.question: A oncologist is developing a clinical prediction model for a time-to-event outcome. The model includes 10 candidate predictors. The expected Cox-Snell R² is 0.15. Using the Riley criteria, what minimum sample size is needed to avoid overfitting and ensure adequate predictive performance?
tasks.reference_code:
library(pmsampsize)
pmsampsize(type="s", csrsquared=0.15, parameters=10, rate=0.15, timepoint=2, meanfup=2.5)

tasks.question: A neurologist is developing a clinical prediction model for a time-to-event outcome. The model includes 20 candidate predictors. The expected Cox-Snell R² is 0.05. Using the Riley criteria, what minimum sample size is needed to avoid overfitting and ensure adequate predictive performance?
tasks.reference_code:
library(pmsampsize)
pmsampsize(type="s", csrsquared=0.05, parameters=20, rate=0.05, timepoint=3, meanfup=4)

tasks.question: A psychiatrist is developing a clinical prediction model for a time-to-event outcome. The model includes 25 candidate predictors. The expected Cox-Snell R² is 0.08. Using the Riley criteria, what minimum sample size is needed to avoid overfitting and ensure adequate predictive performance?
tasks.reference_code:

pmsampsize(type="s", csrsquared=0.08, parameters=25, rate=0.08, timepoint=5, meanfup=4)

tasks.question: A pediatrician is developing a clinical prediction model for a time-to-event outcome. The model includes 30 candidate predictors. The expected Cox-Snell R² is 0.051. Using the Riley criteria, what minimum sample size is needed to avoid overfitting and ensure adequate predictive performance?
tasks.reference_code:

tasks.question: A endocrinologist is developing a clinical prediction model for a time-to-event outcome. The model includes 15 candidate predictors. The expected Cox-Snell R² is 0.12. Using the Riley criteria, what minimum sample size is needed to avoid overfitting and ensure adequate predictive performance?
tasks.reference_code:

pmsampsize(type="s", csrsquared=0.12, parameters=15, rate=0.10, timepoint=3, meanfup=5, shrinkage=0.95)

tasks.question: A orthopedic surgeon is developing a clinical prediction model for a continuous outcome. The model includes 15 candidate predictors. The expected Cox-Snell R² is 0.2. Using the Riley criteria, what minimum sample size is needed to avoid overfitting and ensure adequate predictive performance?
tasks.reference_code:

pmsampsize(type="c", rsquared=0.20, parameters=15, intercept=50, sd=10)

tasks.question: A gastroenterologist is developing a clinical prediction model for a continuous outcome. The model includes 10 candidate predictors. The expected Cox-Snell R² is 0.3. Using the Riley criteria, what minimum sample size is needed to avoid overfitting and ensure adequate predictive performance?
tasks.reference_code:
library(pmsampsize)
pmsampsize(type="c", rsquared=0.30, parameters=10, intercept=100, sd=15)

tasks.question: A pulmonologist is developing a clinical prediction model for a continuous outcome. The model includes 25 candidate predictors. The expected Cox-Snell R² is 0.1. Using the Riley criteria, what minimum sample size is needed to avoid overfitting and ensure adequate predictive performance?
tasks.reference_code:
library(pmsampsize)
pmsampsize(type="c", rsquared=0.10, parameters=25, intercept=0, sd=1)

tasks.question: A rheumatologist is developing a clinical prediction model for a continuous outcome. The model includes 5 candidate predictors. The expected Cox-Snell R² is 0.5. Using the Riley criteria, what minimum sample size is needed to avoid overfitting and ensure adequate predictive performance?
tasks.reference_code:

tasks.question: A dermatologist is developing a clinical prediction model for a continuous outcome. The model includes 25 candidate predictors. The expected Cox-Snell R² is 0.2. Using the Riley criteria, what minimum sample size is needed to avoid overfitting and ensure adequate predictive performance?
tasks.reference_code:
library(pmsampsize)
pmsampsize(type="c", rsquared=0.20, parameters=25, intercept=1.9, sd=0.6)

tasks.question: A ophthalmologist is developing a clinical prediction model for a continuous outcome. The model includes 25 candidate predictors. The expected Cox-Snell R² is 0.2. Using the Riley criteria, what minimum sample size is needed to avoid overfitting and ensure adequate predictive performance?
tasks.reference_code:
library(pmsampsize)
pmsampsize(type="c", rsquared=0.20, parameters=25, intercept=1.9, sd=0.6, mmoe=1.2)

tasks.question: A nephrologist wants to externally validate a prediction model. The expected outcome prevalence is 20%. The model's C-statistic is 0.8. How many subjects are needed for adequate calibration and discrimination assessment?

A infectious disease specialist wants to externally validate a prediction model. The expected outcome prevalence is 15%. The model's C-statistic is 0.75. How many subjects are needed for adequate calibration and discrimination assessment?

A psychologist wants to externally validate a prediction model. The expected outcome prevalence is 30%. The model's C-statistic is 0.7. How many subjects are needed for adequate calibration and discrimination assessment?

A educational researcher wants to externally validate a prediction model. The expected outcome prevalence is 20%. The model's C-statistic is 0.8. How many subjects are needed for adequate calibration and discrimination assessment?
tasks.reference_code:
library(pmvalsampsize)
pmvalsampsize(type="b", prevalence=0.20, cstatistic=0.80, lpnormal=c(-1.5, 2.0), oeciwidth=0.40, cstatciwidth=0.10)

tasks.question: A epidemiologist wants to externally validate a prediction model. The expected outcome prevalence is 10%. The model's C-statistic is 0.75. How many subjects are needed for adequate calibration and discrimination assessment?
tasks.reference_code:
library(pmvalsampsize)
pmvalsampsize(type="b", prevalence=0.10, cstatistic=0.75, lpnormal=c(-2.5, 1.8), oeciwidth=0.40, cstatciwidth=0.10)

tasks.question: A nurse researcher wants to externally validate a prediction model. The expected outcome prevalence is 30%. The model's C-statistic is 0.85. How many subjects are needed for adequate calibration and discrimination assessment?
tasks.reference_code:
library(pmvalsampsize)
pmvalsampsize(type="b", prevalence=0.30, cstatistic=0.85, lpnormal=c(-1.0, 2.5), oeciwidth=0.30, cstatciwidth=0.08)

tasks.question: A social scientist wants to externally validate a prediction model. The expected outcome prevalence is 25%. The model's C-statistic is 0.78. How many subjects are needed for adequate calibration and discrimination assessment?
tasks.reference_code:
library(pmvalsampsize)
pmvalsampsize(type="b", prevalence=0.25, cstatistic=0.78, lpnormal=c(-1.2, 1.8), csciwidth=0.15)

tasks.question: A pharmacist researcher wants to externally validate a prediction model. The expected outcome prevalence is 2%. The model's C-statistic is 0.8. How many subjects are needed for adequate calibration and discrimination assessment?
tasks.reference_code:
library(pmvalsampsize)
pmvalsampsize(type="b", prevalence=0.018, cstatistic=0.80, lpnormal=c(-5, 2.5), oeciwidth=1)

tasks.question: A gerontologist wants to externally validate a prediction model. The expected outcome prevalence is 2%. The model's C-statistic is 0.8. How many subjects are needed for adequate calibration and discrimination assessment?
tasks.reference_code:
library(pmvalsampsize)
pmvalsampsize(type="b", prevalence=0.018, cstatistic=0.80, lpbeta=c(0.5, 0.5), oeciwidth=1)

tasks.question: A sports medicine physician wants to externally validate a prediction model. The expected outcome prevalence is 2%. The model's C-statistic is 0.8. How many subjects are needed for adequate calibration and discrimination assessment?
tasks.reference_code:
library(pmvalsampsize)
pmvalsampsize(type="b", prevalence=0.018, cstatistic=0.80, lpcstat=-4.7, oeciwidth=1, seed=1234, simobs=10000)

tasks.question: A allergist wants to externally validate a prediction model. The expected outcome prevalence is 15%. The model's C-statistic is 0.82. How many subjects are needed for adequate calibration and discrimination assessment?
tasks.reference_code:
library(pmvalsampsize)
pmvalsampsize(type="b", prevalence=0.15, cstatistic=0.82, lpnormal=c(-1.75, 2.16), oeciwidth=0.35, cstatciwidth=0.10, cslope=0.9)

tasks.question: A urologist wants to externally validate a prediction model. The expected outcome prevalence is 5%. The model's C-statistic is 0.9. How many subjects are needed for adequate calibration and discrimination assessment?
tasks.reference_code:
library(pmvalsampsize)
pmvalsampsize(type="b", prevalence=0.05, cstatistic=0.90, lpnormal=c(-3.0, 1.8), oeciwidth=0.50, cstatciwidth=0.05)

tasks.question: A hematologist wants to externally validate a prediction model. The expected outcome prevalence is 20%. The model's C-statistic is 0.8. How many subjects are needed for adequate calibration and discrimination assessment?
tasks.reference_code:
library(pmvalsampsize)
pmvalsampsize(type="b", prevalence=0.20, cstatistic=0.80, lpnormal=c(-1.5, 2.0), threshold=0.3)

tasks.question: A clinical nutritionist wants to externally validate a prediction model. The expected outcome prevalence is 10%. The model's C-statistic is 0.85. How many subjects are needed for adequate calibration and discrimination assessment?
tasks.reference_code:
library(pmvalsampsize)
pmvalsampsize(type="b", prevalence=0.10, cstatistic=0.85, lpnormal=c(-2.5, 2.0), threshold=0.15, oeciwidth=0.40)

tasks.question: A rehabilitation specialist wants to externally validate a prediction model. The expected outcome prevalence is 20%. The model's C-statistic is 0.8. How many subjects are needed for adequate calibration and discrimination assessment?
tasks.reference_code:
library(pmvalsampsize)
pmvalsampsize(type="b", prevalence=0.20, cstatistic=0.80, lpnormal=c(-1.5, 2.0), oe=0.9, oeciwidth=0.30)

tasks.question: A nephrologist wants to estimate a proportion with a desired 95% confidence interval width of 0.1. The expected proportion is 0.3. How many subjects are needed for this precision?
A infectious disease specialist wants to estimate a proportion with a desired 95% confidence interval width of 0.1. The expected proportion is 0.5. How many subjects are needed for this precision?
A psychologist wants to estimate a proportion with a desired 95% confidence interval width of 0.1. The expected proportion is 0.2. How many subjects are needed for this precision?
A educational researcher wants to estimate a proportion with a desired 95% confidence interval width of 0.05. The expected proportion is 0.1. How many subjects are needed for this precision?
A epidemiologist wants to estimate a proportion with a desired 99% confidence interval width of 0.05. The expected proportion is 0.3. How many subjects are needed for this precision?
A nurse researcher wants to estimate a proportion with a desired 95% confidence interval width of 0.05. The expected proportion is 0.5. How many subjects are needed for this precision?
A social scientist wants to estimate a proportion with a desired 95% confidence interval width of 0.04. The expected proportion is 0.05. How many subjects are needed for this precision?
A pharmacist researcher wants to estimate a mean with a desired 95% confidence interval width of 5. The expected SD is 10. How many subjects are needed for this precision?
A gerontologist wants to estimate a mean with a desired 95% confidence interval width of 5. The expected SD is 15. How many subjects are needed for this precision?
A sports medicine physician wants to estimate a mean with a desired 95% confidence interval width of 3. The expected SD is 10. How many subjects are needed for this precision?
A allergist wants to estimate a mean with a desired 99% confidence interval width of 5. The expected SD is 10. How many subjects are needed for this precision?
A urologist wants to estimate a mean with a desired 95% confidence interval width of 0.5. The expected SD is 1. How many subjects are needed for this precision?
A hematologist wants to estimate a mean with a desired 95% confidence interval width of 8. How many subjects are needed for this precision?
A clinical nutritionist wants to estimate a mean with a desired 95% confidence interval width of 4. How many subjects are needed for this precision?
tasks.reference_code:
library(presize)
prec_meandiff(delta=2, sd1=5, sd2=6, conf.width=4, conf.level=0.95, variance="unequal")

tasks.question: A rehabilitation specialist wants to estimate a correlation coefficient with a desired 95% confidence interval width of 0.2. The expected correlation is 0.5. How many subjects are needed for this precision?

A occupational therapist wants to estimate a correlation coefficient with a desired 95% confidence interval width of 0.2. The expected correlation is 0.3. How many subjects are needed for this precision?

A speech pathologist wants to estimate a correlation coefficient with a desired 95% confidence interval width of 0.15. The expected correlation is 0.5. How many subjects are needed for this precision?
A physical therapist wants to estimate a correlation coefficient with a desired 95% confidence interval width of 0.1. The expected correlation is 0.7. How many subjects are needed for this precision?
A cardiologist wants to estimate an event rate with a desired 95% confidence interval width of 0.05. The expected rate is 0.1. How many subjects are needed for this precision?
A oncologist wants to estimate an event rate with a desired 95% confidence interval width of 0.03. The expected rate is 0.05. How many subjects are needed for this precision?
A neurologist wants to estimate an event rate with a desired 95% confidence interval width of 0.1. The expected rate is 0.2. How many subjects are needed for this precision?
A psychiatrist wants to estimate an odds ratio with a desired 95% confidence interval width of 0.5. How many subjects are needed for this precision?
tasks.reference_code:
library(presize)
prec_or(p1=0.30, p2=0.20, conf.width=0.50, conf.level=0.95, method="indip_smooth")

tasks.question: A pediatrician wants to estimate an odds ratio with a desired 95% confidence interval width of 0.8. How many subjects are needed for this precision?
tasks.reference_code:
library(presize)
prec_or(p1=0.40, p2=0.20, conf.width=0.80, conf.level=0.95, method="indip_smooth")

tasks.question: A endocrinologist wants to estimate a risk ratio with a desired 95% confidence interval width of 0.5. How many subjects are needed for this precision?
tasks.reference_code:
library(presize)
prec_riskratio(p1=0.30, p2=0.20, conf.width=0.50, conf.level=0.95, method="koopman")

tasks.question: A orthopedic surgeon wants to estimate a risk ratio with a desired 95% confidence interval width of 0.3. How many subjects are needed for this precision?
tasks.reference_code:
library(presize)
prec_riskratio(p1=0.15, p2=0.10, conf.width=0.30, conf.level=0.95, method="koopman")

tasks.question: A gastroenterologist wants to estimate a risk ratio with a desired 95% confidence interval width of 0.15. How many subjects are needed for this precision?
tasks.reference_code:
library(presize)
prec_riskdiff(p1=0.30, p2=0.20, conf.width=0.15, conf.level=0.95, method="newcombe")

tasks.question: A pulmonologist wants to estimate Cohen's kappa with a desired 95% confidence interval width of 0.2. How many subjects are needed for this precision?
tasks.reference_code:
library(presize)
prec_kappa(kappa=0.60, conf.width=0.20, conf.level=0.95, raters=2, n_category=3, props=c(0.4, 0.3, 0.3))

tasks.question: A rheumatologist wants to estimate Cohen's kappa with a desired 95% confidence interval width of 0.2. How many subjects are needed for this precision?
tasks.reference_code:
library(presize)
prec_kappa(kappa=0.80, conf.width=0.20, conf.level=0.95, raters=2, n_category=2, props=c(0.5, 0.5))

tasks.question: A dermatologist wants to estimate diagnostic sensitivity with a desired 95% confidence interval width of 0.1. How many subjects are needed for this precision?
A ophthalmologist wants to estimate diagnostic sensitivity with a desired 95% confidence interval width of 0.15. How many subjects are needed for this precision?
A nephrologist wants to estimate diagnostic specificity with a desired 95% confidence interval width of 0.05. How many subjects are needed for this precision?
A infectious disease specialist wants to estimate diagnostic specificity with a desired 95% confidence interval width of 0.1. How many subjects are needed for this precision?
A psychologist wants to estimate the area under the ROC curve (AUC) with a desired 95% confidence interval width of 0.1. How many subjects are needed for this precision?
A educational researcher wants to estimate the area under the ROC curve (AUC) with a desired 95% confidence interval width of 0.08. How many subjects are needed for this precision?
A epidemiologist wants to estimate the intraclass correlation coefficient with a desired 95% confidence interval width of 0.2. How many subjects are needed for this precision?
A nurse researcher wants to estimate Cronbach's alpha with a desired 95% confidence interval width of 0.1. How many subjects are needed for this precision?
A social scientist wants to estimate a parameter of interest with a desired 95% confidence interval width of 0.5. How many subjects are needed for this precision?

A pulmonologist is planning an observational study of migraine and wants to estimate the odds ratio with adequate precision. The expected proportions are 0.4 in the exposed group and 0.25 in the unexposed group. Using the gart method at 95% confidence, how many subjects per group are needed to achieve a CI width no greater than 0.8 on the log-odds ratio scale?
tasks.reference_code:
library(presize)
prec_or(p1=0.40, p2=0.25, conf.width=0.80, conf.level=0.95, method="gart")

tasks.question: A rheumatologist is planning an observational study of hypertension and wants to estimate the odds ratio with adequate precision. The expected proportions are 0.3 in the exposed group and 0.15 in the unexposed group. Using the woolf method at 95% confidence, how many subjects per group are needed to achieve a CI width no greater than 1.0 on the log-odds ratio scale?
tasks.reference_code:
library(presize)
prec_or(p1=0.30, p2=0.15, conf.width=1.0, conf.level=0.95, method="woolf")

tasks.question: A dermatologist is designing a comparative study of two treatments for type 2 diabetes. The expected event rates are 30% and 20%. Using the newcombe method, how many subjects per group are required to estimate the risk difference with a 95% CI width no wider than 0.15?
tasks.reference_code:
library(presize)
prec_riskdiff(p1=0.30, p2=0.20, conf.width=0.15, conf.level=0.95, method="newcombe")

tasks.question: A ophthalmologist is designing a comparative study of two treatments for major depressive disorder. The expected event rates are 25% and 10%. Using the mn method, how many subjects per group are required to estimate the risk difference with a 95% CI width no wider than 0.2?
tasks.reference_code:
library(presize)
prec_riskdiff(p1=0.25, p2=0.10, conf.width=0.20, conf.level=0.95, method="mn")

tasks.question: A nephrologist is evaluating inter-rater reliability of a diagnostic assessment for chronic pain. The expected intraclass correlation coefficient (ICC) is 0.7 based on 3 raters per subject. How many subjects are needed to estimate the ICC with a 95% CI width no wider than 0.2?

A infectious disease specialist is evaluating inter-rater reliability of a diagnostic assessment for asthma. The expected intraclass correlation coefficient (ICC) is 0.8 based on 4 raters per subject. How many subjects are needed to estimate the ICC with a 95% CI width no wider than 0.15?

A psychologist is conducting a method comparison study for a measurement used in COPD management. With 100 paired measurements, what is the expected 95% CI width for the Bland-Altman limits of agreement (expressed as a multiple of the standard deviation of differences)?

A educational researcher is designing a method comparison study for a diagnostic measurement in rheumatoid arthritis. How many paired measurements are needed to estimate the Bland-Altman limits of agreement with a 95% CI width no wider than 0.5 times the SD of differences?
A epidemiologist wants to estimate the mean outcome in patients with breast cancer with a standard deviation of 15. How many patients are needed to achieve a 99% CI width no wider than 5?

An nurse researcher is studying the incidence rate of adverse events in heart failure, expecting a rate of 0.05 events per person-year. Using the score method, how many events need to be observed to estimate the rate with a 95% CI width no wider than 0.03?

A social scientist is validating a wearable sensor for arrhythmia detection. The expected sensitivity is 0.8, and the clinically acceptable margin (delta) is 0.1. At significance level 0.05 with 80% power, how many diseased subjects are needed to confirm that the true sensitivity exceeds 0.7000000000000001?

A pharmacist researcher is validating a rapid antigen test for respiratory infections. The expected sensitivity is 0.85, and the clinically acceptable margin (delta) is 0.05. At significance level 0.05 with 90% power, how many diseased subjects are needed to confirm that the true sensitivity exceeds 0.7999999999999999?

A gerontologist is validating a new blood biomarker panel for early cancer detection. The expected specificity is 0.8, and the clinically acceptable margin (delta) is 0.15. At significance level 0.05 with 80% power, how many diseased subjects are needed to confirm that the true specificity exceeds 0.65?

A sports medicine physician is validating a treatment satisfaction scale with 10 items for patients with chronic kidney disease. The expected Cronbach's alpha is 0.85. How many subjects are needed to estimate Cronbach's alpha with a 95% CI width no wider than 0.1?

A allergist is validating a psychological wellbeing inventory with 5 items for patients with inflammatory bowel disease. The expected Cronbach's alpha is 0.9. How many subjects are needed to estimate Cronbach's alpha with a 95% CI width no wider than 0.08?

A urologist is studying agreement among 3 raters classifying patients into 4 diagnostic categories for migraine. The expected Cohen's kappa is 0.6 with category prevalences of 40%, 30%, 20%, and 10%. How many subjects are needed to estimate kappa with a 95% CI width no wider than 0.2?
tasks.reference_code:
library(presize)
prec_kappa(kappa=0.60, raters=3, n_category=4, props=c(0.4,0.3,0.2,0.1), conf.width=0.20, conf.level=0.95)

tasks.question: A hematologist needs to establish a reference range for a biomarker in hypertension. The goal is a 95% reference interval with 90% confidence that the coverage probability is within delta = 0.02 of the nominal level. How many healthy reference subjects are needed?

A clinical nutritionist is developing a clinical prediction model for type 2 diabetes with a binary outcome (prevalence = 0.25). The model will include 15 candidate predictors with an anticipated Nagelkerke R² of 0.2. Using Riley et al.'s criteria for adequate shrinkage, calibration, and precision, what is the minimum required sample size?

A rehabilitation specialist is building a prediction model for a continuous outcome in major depressive disorder (mean = 100, SD = 20) with 12 predictors. The expected R² is 0.35 and the maximum allowable margin of estimation error (MMOE) is 1.15. What minimum sample size satisfies Riley et al.'s criteria?
tasks.reference_code:
library(pmsampsize)
pmsampsize(type="c", rsquared=0.35, parameters=12, intercept=100, sd=20, mmoe=1.15)

tasks.question: A cardiologist is developing a prognostic model for chronic pain with 15 candidate predictors. The expected event rate is 0.1 per person-year, with mean follow-up of 2 years and prediction horizon of 3 years. The anticipated Cox-Snell R² is 0.1. What is the minimum sample size per Riley et al.'s framework?
tasks.reference_code:
library(pmsampsize)
pmsampsize(type="s", csrsquared=0.10, parameters=15, rate=0.10, timepoint=3, meanfup=2)

tasks.question: A oncologist is planning an external validation study for a prognostic model in asthma (prevalence = 0.15, expected C-statistic = 0.85). The validation must achieve adequate precision for calibration slope, calibration-in-the-large, and discrimination. What is the minimum required sample size?
tasks.reference_code:
library(pmvalsampsize)
pmvalsampsize(type="b", prevalence=0.15, cstatistic=0.85, lpnormal=c(-2.0, 1.5), csciwidth=0.05)

tasks.question: A neurologist is planning an external validation study for a prognostic model in COPD (prevalence = 0.1, expected C-statistic = 0.8). The validation must achieve adequate precision for calibration slope, calibration-in-the-large, and discrimination. What is the minimum required sample size?
tasks.reference_code:
library(pmvalsampsize)
pmvalsampsize(type="b", prevalence=0.10, cstatistic=0.80, lpnormal=c(-2.5, 2.0), threshold=0.15)
